text:
It seems that there is an issue with a docker compose based containers on our server
Something related to a custom docker network dns resolution
I've added
```    dns:
      - 8.8.8.8
      - 1.1.1.1```
into the validator service and now it works
I'll continue with setting up the validator.
Thanks!

text:
Can someone explain the implications of "pre-approve incoming direct transfers of Canton Coin" in the wallet UI?
If I don't do this, would transfers fail?  Or require manual appoval of each?
Is pre-approving recommended?
Thanks!

elements.text:

If I don't do this, would transfers fail?  Or require manual appoval of each?
Is pre-approving recommended?
Thanks!

text:
I suspect if the following was placed correctly in the yaml.
```# Uncomment the following block if you want to restore from a participant dump
# and recover your balance
# PARTICIPANT_BOOTSTRAP_MIGRATE_TO_NEW_PARTICIPANT_START
# participantIdentitiesDumpImport:
#   secretName: participant-bootstrap-dump
#   # Make sure to also adjust nodeIdentifier to the same value
#   newParticipantIdentifier: put-some-new-string-never-used-before
# migrateValidatorParty: true
# PARTICIPANT_BOOTSTRAP_MIGRATE_TO_NEW_PARTICIPANT_END```

elements.text: I suspect if the following was placed correctly in the yaml.

# Uncomment the following block if you want to restore from a participant dump
# and recover your balance
# PARTICIPANT_BOOTSTRAP_MIGRATE_TO_NEW_PARTICIPANT_START
# participantIdentitiesDumpImport:
#   secretName: participant-bootstrap-dump
#   # Make sure to also adjust nodeIdentifier to the same value
#   newParticipantIdentifier: put-some-new-string-never-used-before
# migrateValidatorParty: true
# PARTICIPANT_BOOTSTRAP_MIGRATE_TO_NEW_PARTICIPANT_END

text: <https://chataai.slack.com/archives/C08AP9QR7K4/p1746679301615549?thread_ts=1746640641.993189&cid=C08AP9QR7K4>

text:
document should work.

the issue is likely sth with your host that cannot resolve localhost domain.

You can hard code `wallet.localhost` etc into your `/etc/hosts` to resolve to `127.0.0.1`

<https://github.com/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/blob/main/cluster/compose/validator/nginx.conf>

these domains are defined on that file. You can also replace them with something that resolve to 127.0.0.1 or your private node lan ip.

as long as the domain resolve to the right ip. and the domain match the right one in nginx.conf above, it will be routed to right service.

attachments.text: Contribute to digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync development by creating an account on GitHub.
attachments.title: decentralized-canton-sync/cluster/compose/validator/nginx.conf at main · digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync

document should work.

the issue is likely sth with your host that cannot resolve localhost domain.

You can hard code
wallet.localhost
etc into your
/etc/hosts
to resolve to

these domains are defined on that file. You can also replace them with something that resolve to 127.0.0.1 or your private node lan ip.

as long as the domain resolve to the right ip. and the domain match the right one in nginx.conf above, it will be routed to right service.

``` "id": "PAR::chata-dev-1::12203dae04428d022cabccf2fca834c2e761aba5ee67e1e5ded4d7c760f527a329ba",```

text:
keep
> Aunt Moritz  [2:09 PM]
> wouldn't recommend it, it's too easy to miss something or get confused by holding fees that way (due to the normalization to round 0)
> Instead rather than querying the holding summary query the ACS for locked and unlocked amulet at record time for that party. Then consume the update stream and look for CreatedEvents that created new amulet/locked amulet and consuming ExrecisedEvent that archive amulet/locked amulet. That way you get the ACS at whatever record time you want and then you just need to sum up the amulets

elements.text: keep

Aunt Moritz  [2:09 PM]
wouldn't recommend it, it's too easy to miss something or get confused by holding fees that way (due to the normalization to round 0)
Instead rather than querying the holding summary query the ACS for locked and unlocked amulet at record time for that party. Then consume the update stream and look for CreatedEvents that created new amulet/locked amulet and consuming ExrecisedEvent that archive amulet/locked amulet. That way you get the ACS at whatever record time you want and then you just need to sum up the amulets

text: Hi Team, we are trying to do restore from Node Identities Backup. As part of this, we have created the secret using the Node Identities Backup file and uncommented in standalone-validator-values.yaml. But every time we do restore, a new party ID and we are unable to see the actual coin balance. Our original party ID is `chata-dev-1::12203dae04428d022cabccf2fca834c2e761aba5ee67e1e5ded4d7c760f527a329ba` but on installed the restore, it changed to `chata-dev-1::1220df963b700c25e1691b86c542f5876ddc9f0f9995b0210c39be5ba98a44a46221`  and when we installed today, we got a new party id again `chata-dev-1::1220160dc79abfe76a0ed3965e6b19cc646bb09113b78bc49f0e5add5b7931b21021` . Is this expected as part of Node restore using Node Identities dump? Is there anything that actually connects the initial part ID to the one we get after restore?

elements.text: Hi Team, we are trying to do restore from Node Identities Backup. As part of this, we have created the secret using the Node Identities Backup file and uncommented in standalone-validator-values.yaml. But every time we do restore, a new party ID and we are unable to see the actual coin balance. Our original party ID is
chata-dev-1::12203dae04428d022cabccf2fca834c2e761aba5ee67e1e5ded4d7c760f527a329ba
but on installed the restore, it changed to
and when we installed today, we got a new party id again
chata-dev-1::1220160dc79abfe76a0ed3965e6b19cc646bb09113b78bc49f0e5add5b7931b21021
. Is this expected as part of Node restore using Node Identities dump? Is there anything that actually connects the initial part ID to the one we get after restore?
